awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Safe, Affordable and Green Energy Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of the Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide a safe, affordable and environmentally sustainable energy storage solution.  This project offers a non-chemical, non-hazardous alternative energy storage to accelerate grid modernization and non-polluting renewable power integration.  The project’s core technology is a design that is cost competitive with deployed Lithium ion (Li-ion) chemical batteries, but would be significantly less expensive per charge than Li-ion over its 30+ year service life.  This proposed approach allows the long-term advantages of kinetic (flywheel) energy storage (low service life costs, high power throughput, high daily charge cycles, no battery replacements, potential for 24/7 operations) and makes it affordable and safer for deployed stationary grid operations. With solar and wind renewables on par with traditional carbon-based power generation costs, affordable flywheel energy storage is vital to store and dispense intermittent renewable power, enabling the replacement of carbon-based power generation.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes a comprehensive testing effort to verify the technical feasibility of the project’s 3D flywheel composite structure for next-generation energy storage systems. The proposed research and testing objectives are to demonstrate the improved 3D flywheel performance and projected 9x reduction in the traditional flywheel weight for the same energy storage capability. Testing methodology includes dynamic balancing, torque transmission determination, critical failure/fatigue modeling, assessing magnetically coupled commercial external motor/generator power transmission and performance in a TRL-5 operational vacuum environment. The effort will also include energy storage market analysis for commercial market entry based on tested 3D flywheel performance. Anticipated results include the characterization of the 3D flywheel structural technology, demonstrated commercial subsystem operations and readiness to develop a full prototype.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
KineticCore Solutions (KCS) Safe, Affordable, and Green Energy Storage (SAGES) NSF SBIR Phase-1 project has successfully demonstrated all Phase-1 tasks and is prepared to enter system prototyping and pilot deployment in the upcoming Phase-2 program.  The focus of the NSF SBIR Phase-1 effort was to conduct developmental test and evaluation (DT&E) on the next generation prototype KineticCore flywheel structural performance with supporting applied research, modeling & simulation, and testing of the innovative subsystems to take advantage of the low-mass, high-speed flywheel design. Three critical technical milestones were completed in Phase-1 supporting the Phase-2 proposal:

1)     KineticCore flywheel structural performance was confirmed (high speed and 1st vibration mode) as predicted through modeling & simulation and Finite Element Analysis (FEA)

2)     TRL-5 prototype with supporting innovative subsystems was assembled and tested

3)     Demonstrated 1C and 2C power transfer during spin testing of the 25 kWh flywheel unit

Overall, this Phase-1 was a resounding success in advancing flywheel structural state-of-the-art and preparing to field a cost-effective, non-chemical safe alternative to chemical batteries (i.e. Li-ion) for stationary storage capabilities.

The NSF funded SBIR Phase-1 grant directly accelerated KCS to produce and market a product that would meet the national/global need for energy storage left open by inadequate chemical batteries and expensive traditional flywheel systems.  The KCS SAGES system is specifically designed to support our target market commercial & industrial facility peak power loads, and eventually support multiple markets including utility scale renewable integration, smart grid regulation, solar microgrids, and battery “boosted” fast charging stations for fleet and personal Electric Vehicles (EVs).  These markets represent over 800 GWh (~$320B) of global energy storage by 2030 and have three key requirements: high power, high daily duty cycles and low lifecycle costs in potentially high volumes as adoption levels increase. Traditional chemical and flywheel energy storage currently cannot meet all three of these key requirements cost-effectively.


Last Modified: 03/24/2023
Modified by: James B Clegern
